title: Chris Christie Offers Plan to Aid the Middle Class
content:
Gov . Chris Christie of New Jersey returned to the campaign trail on Tuesday in New Hampshire , where he unveiled an economic plan that strikes a theme increasingly common among candidates in both the Republican and Democratic presidential fields : the need to reduce income inequality .
Arguing that the Federal Reserve under President Obama had overseen easy-money policies that have helped fuel the rise in stock prices , he said the major beneficiaries have been those who own equities , while people who depend mainly on their salaries have been left behind .
His cure ? Simplifying the tax code from six brackets to three , reducing income tax rates and eliminating the payroll tax for anyone over age 62 or those entering the workforce under age 21 . The current top income tax rate would drop to 28 percent from 39 percent under his plan , while the corporate rate would decline to 25 percent from 35 percent .
Those at the lowest end of the wage spectrum would see their rates drop to the single digits from 10 percent , though because of tax credits and deductions they often don ’ t face taxes anyway .
Mr. Christie is offering his economic proposals as his campaign has been battered by unwelcome attention to the indictments of a former aide and a political ally in the George Washington Bridge lane closings case .
His oratorical jabs in unveiling his plan were focused on both the Obama administration and the Federal Reserve , a favored target of the Republican presidential field this year .
“ The weak economy combined with a set of monetary policies in these last six years geared for the wealthy have exacerbated the very problem the left loves to harp on – that of income inequality , ” he said . “ In the stronger , higher growth economy we enjoyed in the 1980s and 1990s , incomes grew for most Americans . ”
Holly Shulman , a spokeswoman for the Democratic National Committee , belittled the Christie plan as yet another Republican gift to the wealthy .
“ The one thing Christie has made clear about his tax plan so far : It cuts taxes for the wealthiest and corporations , ” she said . “ And what would he do for the middle class ? Unclear . This shows again where the Republican Party stands – prioritizing tax cuts for the wealthy and corporations above all else . ”
Mr. Christie , who has not yet officially declared himself as a presidential candidate , has distinguished himself in the Republican field by saying climate change is a real issue and is caused by human activity . Nonetheless , he promised a “ pro-growth ” energy strategy that “ unlocks the full potential of the North American energy renaissance ” and said that he would reduce regulation of the energy industry and revoke the Obama administration ’ s “ most egregious and unlawful rules and executive orders . ”
He took particular aim at the administration ’ s 2014 executive order designed to curb emissions from coal-fired power plants by 30 percent .
“ Using a very novel interpretation of section 111 ( d ) of the Clean Air Act – an interpretation which will of course be challenged in the courts – the administration is not only trying to prevent new coal-fired electric plants from being built , it is one-by-one trying to force the closure of existing plants , ” he said .
Republicans have criticized the president for using the executive orders to combat emissions from power plants and vehicles , saying such acts threaten the economy .

Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey returned to the campaign trail on Tuesday in New Hampshire, where he unveiled an economic plan that strikes a theme increasingly common among candidates in both the Republican and Democratic presidential fields: the need to reduce income inequality.

Arguing that the Federal Reserve under President Obama had overseen easy-money policies that have helped fuel the rise in stock prices, he said the major beneficiaries have been those who own equities, while people who depend mainly on their salaries have been left behind.

His cure? Simplifying the tax code from six brackets to three, reducing income tax rates and eliminating the payroll tax for anyone over age 62 or those entering the workforce under age 21. The current top income tax rate would drop to 28 percent from 39 percent under his plan, while the corporate rate would decline to 25 percent from 35 percent.

Those at the lowest end of the wage spectrum would see their rates drop to the single digits from 10 percent, though because of tax credits and deductions they often don’t face taxes anyway.

Mr. Christie is offering his economic proposals as his campaign has been battered by unwelcome attention to the indictments of a former aide and a political ally in the George Washington Bridge lane closings case.

His oratorical jabs in unveiling his plan were focused on both the Obama administration and the Federal Reserve, a favored target of the Republican presidential field this year.

“The weak economy combined with a set of monetary policies in these last six years geared for the wealthy have exacerbated the very problem the left loves to harp on – that of income inequality,” he said. “In the stronger, higher growth economy we enjoyed in the 1980s and 1990s, incomes grew for most Americans.”

Holly Shulman, a spokeswoman for the Democratic National Committee, belittled the Christie plan as yet another Republican gift to the wealthy.

“The one thing Christie has made clear about his tax plan so far: It cuts taxes for the wealthiest and corporations,” she said. “And what would he do for the middle class? Unclear. This shows again where the Republican Party stands – prioritizing tax cuts for the wealthy and corporations above all else.”

Mr. Christie, who has not yet officially declared himself as a presidential candidate, has distinguished himself in the Republican field by saying climate change is a real issue and is caused by human activity. Nonetheless, he promised a “pro-growth” energy strategy that “unlocks the full potential of the North American energy renaissance” and said that he would reduce regulation of the energy industry and revoke the Obama administration’s “most egregious and unlawful rules and executive orders.”

He took particular aim at the administration’s 2014 executive order designed to curb emissions from coal-fired power plants by 30 percent.

“Using a very novel interpretation of section 111(d) of the Clean Air Act – an interpretation which will of course be challenged in the courts – the administration is not only trying to prevent new coal-fired electric plants from being built, it is one-by-one trying to force the closure of existing plants,” he said.

Republicans have criticized the president for using the executive orders to combat emissions from power plants and vehicles, saying such acts threaten the economy.
